[[Image:Polythiophene repeat unit.png|thumb|The monomer repeat unit of unsubstituted polythiophene.]] [[Image:Polythiophenes fluorescence NMR tube.jpg|thumb|Polythiophenes demonstrate interesting optical properties resulting from their conjugated backbone, as demonstrated by the [[fluorescence]] of a substituted polythiophene solution under UV irradiation.]]
'''Polythiophenes''' (PTs) are [[polymer]]ized [[thiophene]]s, a [[sulfur]] [[heterocyclic compound|heterocycle]]. They can become [[Conductive polymer|conducting]] when oxidized. The study of polythiophenes and related conductive polymers was recognized by the awarding of the 2000 [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry]] to [[Alan J. Heeger]], [[Alan MacDiarmid]], and [[Hideki Shirakawa]] "for the discovery and development of conductive polymers". The most notable property of these materials, [[electrical resistivity and conductivity|electrical conductivity]], results from the [[Delocalized electron|delocalization of electrons]] along the polymer backbone – hence the term "synthetic metals". Conductivity however is not the only interesting property resulting from electron delocalization. The optical properties of these materials respond to environmental stimuli, with dramatic color shifts in response to changes in [[solvent]], [[temperature]], [[Electric potential|applied potential]], and binding to other molecules. Changes in both color and conductivity are induced by the same mechanism, twisting of the polymer backbone and disrupting conjugation, making conjugated polymers attractive as [[Sensor#Chemical sensors|sensors]] that can provide a range of optical and electronic responses.
A number of comprehensive [[review]]s have been published on PTs, the earliest dating from 1981.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Street |first1=G. B. |last2=Clarke |first2=T. C. |title=Conducting Polymers: A Review of Recent Work |journal=IBM J. Res. Dev. |year=1981 |volume=25 |pages=51–57 |doi=10.1147/rd.251.0051}}</ref> Schopf and Koßmehl published a comprehensive review of the literature published between 1990 and 1994.<ref name="schopf_and_kossmehl_1997">{{cite journal |last1=Schopf |first1=G. |last2=Koßmehl |first2=G. |title=Polythiophenes—Electrically Conducting Polymers |journal=Adv. Polym. Sci. |year=1997 |volume=129 |pages=1–166 |doi=10.1007/BFb0008700 |series=Advances in Polymer Science |isbn=3-540-61857-0}}</ref> Roncali surveyed electrochemical synthesis in 1992,<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/cr00012a009|title=Conjugated poly(thiophenes): synthesis, functionalization, and applications|year=1992|last1=Roncali|first1=Jean|journal=Chemical Reviews|volume=92|pages=711|issue=4}}</ref> and the electronic properties of substituted PTs in 1997.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/cr950257t|pmid=11848868|title=Synthetic Principles for Bandgap Control in Linear π-Conjugated Systems|year=1997|last1=Roncali|first1=Jean|journal=Chemical Reviews|volume=97|issue=1|pages=173–206}}</ref> McCullough's 1998 review focussed on chemical synthesis of conducting PTs.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=McCullough|first1=Richard D.|title=The Chemistry of Conducting Polythiophenes|journal=Advanced Materials|volume=10|pages=93|year=1998|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1521-4095(199801)10:2<93::AID-ADMA93>3.0.CO;2-F|issue=2}}</ref> A general review of conjugated polymers from the 1990s was conducted by Reddinger and Reynolds in 1999.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Reddinger |first1=J. L. |last2=Reynolds |first2=J. R. |title=Molecular Engineering of p-Conjugated Polymers |journal=Adv. Polym. Sci. |volume=145 |pages=57–122 |year=1999 |doi=10.1007/3-540-70733-6_2 |series=Advances in Polymer Science |isbn=978-3-540-65210-6}}</ref> Finally, [[Timothy M. Swager|Swager]] ''et al.'' examined conjugated-polymer-based chemical sensors in 2000.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/cr9801014|pmid=11749295|title=Conjugated Polymer-Based Chemical Sensors|year=2000|last1=McQuade|first1=D. Tyler|last2=Pullen|first2=Anthony E.|last3=Swager|first3=Timothy M.|journal=Chemical Reviews|volume=100|issue=7|pages=2537–74}}</ref> These reviews are an excellent guide to the highlights of the primary PT literature from the last two decades.
==Mechanism of conductivity and doping== Electrons are delocalized along the conjugated backbones of conducting polymers, usually through overlap of π-orbitals, resulting in an extended π-system with a filled valence band. By removing electrons from the π-system ("p-doping"), or adding electrons into the π-system ("n-doping"), a charged unit called a [[bipolaron]] is formed (see Figure 1). [[Image:Polythiophenes Bipolaron.png|frame|'''Figure 1.''' Removal of two electrons (p-doping) from a PT chain produces a bipolaron.]] Doping is performed at much higher levels (20–40%) in conducting polymers than in semiconductors (<1%). The bipolaron moves as a unit along the polymer chain, and is responsible for the macroscopically observed conductivity of the polymer. For some samples of [[poly(3-dodecylthiophene)]] doped with [[iodine]], the conductivity can approach 1000 S/cm.<ref name="mccullough_etal_1993">{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ja00064a070|title=Self-orienting head-to-tail poly(3-alkylthiophenes): new insights on structure-property relationships in conducting polymers|year=1993|last1=McCullough|first1=Richard D.|last2=Tristram-Nagle|first2=Stephanie|last3=Williams|first3=Shawn P.|last4=Lowe|first4=Renae D.|last5=Jayaraman|first5=Manikandan|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|volume=115|pages=4910|issue=11}}</ref> (In comparison, the conductivity of [[copper]] is approximately 5×10<sup>5</sup> S/cm.) Generally, the conductivity of PTs is lower than 1000 S/cm, but high conductivity is not necessary for many applications of conducting polymers (see [[Polythiophene#Applications|below]] for examples).
Simultaneous oxidation of the conducting polymer and introduction of counterions, p-doping, can be accomplished [[Electrochemistry|electrochemically]] or [[Chemistry|chemically]]. During the electrochemical synthesis of a PT, counterions dissolved in the solvent can associate with the polymer as it is deposited onto the electrode in its oxidized form. By doping the polymer as it is synthesized, a thick film can build up on an electrode—the polymer conducts electrons from the substrate to the surface of the film. Alternatively, a neutral conducting polymer film or solution can be doped post-synthesis.
Reduction of the conducting polymer, n-doping, is much less common than p-doping. An early study of electrochemical n-doping of [[poly(bithiophene)]] found that the n-doping levels are less than those of p-doping, the n-doping cycles were less efficient, the number of cycles required to reach maximum doping was higher, and the n-doping process appeared to be kinetically limited, possibly due to counterion diffusion in the polymer.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/0013-4686(90)87029-2|title=Electrochemical characterization of "n" doped polyheterocyclic conducting polymers—I. Polybithiophene|year=1990|last1=Mastragostino|first1=M.|last2=Soddu|first2=L.|journal=Electrochimica Acta|volume=35|pages=463|issue=2}}</ref>
A variety of reagents have been used to dope PTs. ==Structure and optical properties==
===Conjugation length and chromisms=== The extended π-systems of conjugated PTs produce some of the most interesting properties of these materials—their optical properties. As an approximation, the conjugated backbone can be considered as a real-world example of the "electron-in-a-box" solution to the [[Schrödinger equation]]; however, the development of refined models to accurately predict [[Absorption spectroscopy|absorption]] and [[Fluorescence spectroscopy|fluorescence]] spectra of well-defined oligo(thiophene) systems is ongoing.<ref>Bässler, H. "Electronic Excitation". In ''Electronic Materials: The Oligomer Approach''; Müllen, K.; Wegner, G., Eds.; Wiley-VCH: Weinheim, Germany, 1998, {{ISBN|3-527-29438-4}}</ref> Conjugation relies upon overlap of the π-orbitals of the [[Aromaticity|aromatic rings]], which, in turn, requires the thiophene rings to be coplanar (see Figure 2, top). [[Image:Polythiophenes Conjugation.png|frame|'''Figure 2.''' Conjugated π-orbitals of a coplanar and a twisted substituted PT.]] The number of coplanar rings determines the conjugation length—the longer the conjugation length, the lower the separation between adjacent [[energy level]]s, and the longer the absorption wavelength. Deviation from coplanarity may be permanent, resulting from mislinkages during synthesis or especially bulky [[side chain]]s; or temporary, resulting from changes in the environment or binding. This twist in the backbone reduces the conjugation length (see Figure 2, bottom), and the separation between energy levels is increased. This results in a shorter absorption wavelength.
Determining the maximum effective conjugation length requires the synthesis of regioregular PTs of defined length. The absorption band in the visible region is increasingly [[Bathochromic shift|red-shifted]] as the conjugation length increases, and the maximum effective conjugation length is calculated as the saturation point of the red-shift. Early studies by ten Hoeve ''et al.'' estimated that the effective conjugation extended over 11 repeat units,<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ja00015a067|title=Substituted .. – undecithiophenes, the longest characterized oligothiophenes|year=1991|last1=Ten Hoeve|first1=W.|last2=Wynberg|first2=H.|last3=Havinga|first3=E. E.|last4=Meijer|first4=E. W.|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|volume=113|pages=5887|issue=15|url=http://library.tue.nl/csp/dare/LinkToRepository.csp?recordnumber=587968}}</ref> while later studies increased this estimate to 20 units.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Meier |first1=H. |last2=Stalmach |first2=U. |last3=Kolshorn |first3=H |title=Effective conjugation length and UV/vis spectra of oligomers |journal=Acta Polymerica |volume=48 |issue=9 |pages=379–384 |date=September 1997 |doi=10.1002/actp.1997.010480905}}</ref> Using the absorbance and emission profile of discrete conjugated oligo(3-hexylthiophene)s prepared through polymerization and separation, Lawrence et al. determined the effective conjugation length of poly(3-hexylthiophene) to be 14 units.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lawrence|first=Jimmy|last2=Goto|first2=Eisuke|last3=Ren|first3=Jing M.|last4=McDearmon|first4=Brenden|last5=Kim|first5=Dong Sub|last6=Ochiai|first6=Yuto|last7=Clark|first7=Paul conjugation length of polythiophene derivatives depend on the chemical structure of side chains,<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/jo981541y|title=Synthesis and Properties of the Longest Oligothiophenes: the Icosamer and Heptacosamer|year=1998|last1=Nakanishi|first1=Hidetaka|last2=Sumi|first2=Naoto|last3=Aso|first3=Yoshio|last4=Otsubo|first4=Tetsuo|journal=The Journal of Organic β-Blocked Long Oligothiophenes up to the 96-mer: Revaluation of Effective Conjugation Length|pmid=12720435|year=2003|last1=Izumi|first1=Tsuyoshi|last2=Kobashi|first2=Seiji|last3=Takimiya|first3=Kazuo|last4=Aso|first4=Yoshio|last5=Otsubo|first5=Tetsuo|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|volume=125|issue=18|pages=5286–7}}</ref>
A variety of environmental factors can cause the conjugated backbone to twist, reducing the conjugation length and causing an absorption band shift, including solvent, temperature, application of an electric field, and dissolved [[ion]]s.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} The absorption band of poly ([[3-Thiophene acetic acid|3-thiophene acetic acid]]) in aqueous solutions of [[Polyvinyl alcohol|poly(vinyl alcohol)]] (PVA) shifts from 480 nm at [[pH]] 7 to 415 nm at pH 4. This is attributed to formation of a compact coil structure, which can form [[hydrogen bond]]s with PVA upon partial deprotonation of the acetic acid group.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0379-6779(00)00453-7|title=Luminescence of poly(3-thiopheneacetic acid) in alcohols and aqueous solutions of poly(vinyl alcohol)|first2=Ernesto C.|year=2001|last2=Pereira|last1=De Souza|first1=J. |journal=Synthetic Metals|volume=118|pages=167}}</ref> [[chirality (chemistry)|Chiral]] PTs showed no [[Circular dichroism|induced circular dichroism]] (ICD) in [[chloroform]], but displayed intense, but opposite, ICDs in chloroform–acetonitrile mixtures versus chloroform–acetone mixtures.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Goto, H. |author2=Yashima, E. |author3=Okamoto, Y. |journal=Chirality|year=2000|volume=12|pages= 396–399|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1520-636X(2000)12:5/6<396::AID-CHIR17>3.0.CO;2-X|pmid=10824159|title=Unusual solvent effects on chiroptical properties of an optically active regioregular polythiophene in solution|issue=5–6}}</ref> Also, a PT with a chiral [[amino acid]] side chain<ref name="andersson_etal_1991">{{cite journal|author1=Andersson, M. |author2=Ekeblad, P. O. |author3=Hjertberg, T. |author4=Wennerström, O. |author5=Inganäs, O.|title=Polythiophene with a free amino-acid side-chain |journal=Polym. Commun.|year=1991|volume=32|pages= 546–548}}</ref> displayed moderate absorption band shifts and ICDs, depending upon the pH and the concentration of [[Buffer solution|buffer]].<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1088/0953-8984/14/42/313|title=Conformational transitions of a free amino-acid-functionalized polythiophene induced by different buffer systems|year=2002|last1=Nilsson|first1=K. P. R. |last2=Andersson|first2=M. R. |last3=Inganäs|first3=O. |journal=Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter|volume=14|pages=10011|issue=42}}</ref>
Shifts in PT absorption bands due to changes in temperature result from a conformational transition from a coplanar, rodlike structure at lower temperatures to a nonplanar, coiled structure at elevated temperatures. For example, poly(3-(octyloxy)-4-methylthiophene) undergoes a color change from red–violet at 25 °C to pale yellow at 150 °C. An [[isosbestic point]] (a point where the absorbance curves at all temperatures overlap) indicates coexistence between two phases, which may exist on the same chain or on different chains.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ma00034a012|title=Rod-to-coil transition in alkoxy-substituted polythiophenes|year=1992|last1=Roux|first1=Claudine|last2=Leclerc|first2=Mario|journal=Macromolecules|volume=25|pages=2141|issue=8}}</ref> Not all thermochromic PTs exhibit an isosbestic point: highly regioregular poly(3-alkylthiophene)s (PATs) show a continuous blue-shift with increasing temperature if the side chains are short enough so that they do not melt and interconvert between crystalline and disordered phases at low temperatures.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}
Finally, PTs can exhibit absorption shifts due to application of electric potentials (electrochromism),<ref name="heuer_etal_2002">{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/1616-3028(20020201)12:2<89::AID-ADFM89>3.0.CO;2-1|title=Electrochromic Window Based on Conducting Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)-Poly(styrene sulfonate)|author1=H. W. Heuer |author2=R. Wehrmann |author3=S. Kirchmeyer |journal=Advanced Functional Materials|volume=12|page= 89|year=2002|issue=2}}</ref> or to introduction of [[Alkali|alkali ions]] (ionochromism).<ref name="marsella_and_swager_1993">{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ja00078a090|title=Designing conducting polymer-based sensors: selective ionochromic response in crown ether-containing polythiophenes|year=1993|last1=Marsella|first1=Michael J.|last2=Swager|first2=Timothy M.|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|volume=115|pages=12214|issue=25}}</ref> These effects will be discussed in the context of applications of PTs below.
===Regioregularity=== The asymmetry of 3-substituted thiophenes results in three possible couplings when two monomers are linked between the 2- and the 5-positions. These couplings are: *2,5', or head–tail (HT), coupling. *2,2', or head–head (HH), coupling *5,5', or tail–tail (TT), coupling These three diads can be combined into four distinct triads, shown in Figure 3. [[Image:Polythiophenes Triads.png|frame|'''Figure 3.'''The four possible triads resulting from coupling of 3-substituted thiophenes.]]The triads are distinguishable by [[nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy|NMR spectroscopy]], and the degree of regioregularity can be estimated by integration.<ref name="barbarella_etal_1994">{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ma00089a022|title=Regiochemistry and Conformation of Poly(3-hexylthiophene) via the Synthesis and the Spectroscopic Characterization of the Model Configurational Triads|year=1994|last1=Barbarella|first1=Giovanna|last2=Bongini|first2=Alessandro|last3=Zambianchi|first3=Massimo|journal=Macromolecules|volume=27|pages=3039|issue=11}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Regiochemical Analysis of Water Soluble Conductive Polymers: Sodium Poly(ω-(3-thienyl)alkanesulfonates)|journal=Macromolecules|year=1996|volume=29|page=5416|author=Diaz-Quijada, G. A.|doi=10.1021/ma960126|issue=16|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
Regioregularity affects the properties of PTs. A regiorandom copolymer of 3-methylthiophene and 3-butylthiophene possessed a conductivity of 50 S/cm, while a more regioregular copolymer with a 2:1 ratio of HT to HH couplings had a higher conductivity of 140 S/cm.<ref>Elsenbaumer, R. L.; Jen, K.-Y.; Miller, G. G.; Eckhardt, H.; Shacklette, L. W.; Jow, R. "Poly (alkyl thiophenes) and Poly (substituted heteroaromatic vinylenes): Versatile, Highly Conductive, Processible Polymers with Tunable Properties". R.|last2=Selse|first2=D.|last3=Berggren|first3=M.|last4=Jaervinen|first4=H.|last5=Hjertberg|first5=T.|last6=Inganaes|first6=O.|last7=Wennerstroem|first7=O.|last8=Oesterholm|first8=J.-E.|journal=Macromolecules|volume=27|pages=6503|issue=22}}</ref> PATs prepared using Rieke [[zinc]] formed "crystalline, flexible, and bronze-colored films with a metallic luster". On the other hand, the corresponding regiorandom polymers produced "amorphous and orange-colored films".<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ja00106a027|title=Regiocontrolled Synthesis of Poly(3-alkylthiophenes) Mediated by Rieke Zinc: Their Characterization and Solid-State Properties|year=1995|last1=Chen|first1=Tian-An|last2=Wu|first2=Xiaoming|last3=Rieke|first3=Reuben D.|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|volume=117|pages=233}}</ref> Comparison of the thermochromic properties of the Rieke PATs showed that, while the regioregular polymers showed strong thermochromic effects, the absorbance spectra of the regioirregular polymers did not change significantly at elevated temperatures. This was likely due to the formation of only weak and localized conformational defects.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} Finally, Xu and Holdcroft demonstrated that the fluorescence absorption and emission maxima of poly(3-hexylthiophene)s occur at increasingly lower wavelengths (higher energy) with increasing HH dyad content. The difference between absorption and emission maxima, the [[Stokes shift]], also increases with HH dyad content, which they attributed to greater relief from conformational strain in the first excited state.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ma00069a009|title=Molecular control of luminescence from poly(3-hexylthiophenes)|year=1993|last1=Xu|first1=Bai|last2=Holdcroft|first2=Steven|journal=Macromolecules|volume=26|pages=4457|issue=17}}</ref>

Elsenbaumer ''et al.'', using a [[nickel]]-catalyzed [[Grignard reaction|Grignard]] cross-coupling, synthesized two soluble PTs, poly(3-butylthiophene) and poly(3-methylthiophene-'co'-3'-octylthiophene), which could be cast into films and doped with iodine to reach conductivities of 4 to 6 S/cm.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/0379-6779(86)90020-2|title=Processible and environmentally stable conducting polymers☆|year=1986|last1=Elsenbaumer|first1=R. |last2=Jen|first2=K. |last3=Oboodi|first3=R. |journal=Synthetic Metals|volume=15|pages=169|issue=2–3}}</ref> Hotta ''et al.'' synthesized poly(3-butylthiophene) and poly(3-hexylthiophene) electrochemically<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ma00167a038|title=Spectroscopic studies of soluble poly(3-alkylthienylenes)|year=1987|last1=Hotta|first1=S.|last2=Rughooputh|first2=S. ==Synthesis== PTs can be synthesized electrochemically, by applying a potential across a solution of the monomer, or chemically, using [[Oxidizing agent|oxidants]] or [[Coupling reaction|cross-coupling]] catalysts. All methods have their advantages and disadvantages.
===Electrochemical synthesis=== In an electrochemical polymerization, a solution containing thiophene and an [[electrolyte]] produces a conductive PT film on the [[anode]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} Electrochemical polymerization is convenient, since the polymer does not need to be isolated and purified, but it can produce polymers with undesirable alpha-beta linkages and varying degrees of regioregularity.
[[Image:Polythiophenes Electropolymerization.png|frame|'''Figure 4.''' Initial steps in the electropolymerization of thiophenes.]]
As shown in Figure 4, oxidation of a monomer produces a [[Radical ion|radical cation]], which can then couple with a second radical cation to form a dication dimer, or with another monomer to produce a radical cation dimer. Deposition of long, well-ordered chains onto the electrode surface is followed by growth of either long, flexible chains, or shorter, more crosslinked chains, depending upon the polymerization conditions.
The quality of an electrochemically prepared PT film is affected by a number of factors. These include the electrode material, current density, temperature, solvent, electrolyte, presence of water, and monomer concentration.<ref name="schopf_and_kossmehl_1997" /> Two other important but interrelated factors are the structure of the monomer and the applied potential. The potential required to oxidize the monomer depends upon the electron density in the thiophene ring π-system. Electron-donating groups lower the oxidation potential, while electron-withdrawing groups increase the oxidation potential. Thus, 3-methylthiophene polymerizes in acetonitrile and tetrabutylammonium tetrafluoroborate at a potential of about 1.5 V vs. SCE ([[saturated calomel electrode]]), while unsubstituted thiophene polymerizes at about 1.7 V vs. SCE. [[Steric effects|Steric hindrance]] resulting from branching at the α-carbon of a 3-substituted thiophene inhibits polymerization.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/j100311a030|title=Effects of steric factors on the electrosynthesis and properties of conducting poly(3-alkylthiophenes)|year=1987|last1=Roncali|first1=J.|last2=Garreau|first2=R.|last3=Yassar|first3=A.|last4=Marque|first4=P.|last5=Garnier|first5=F.|last6=Lemaire|first6=M.|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry|volume=91|pages=6706|issue=27}}</ref> This observation leads to the so-called "polythiophene paradox": the oxidation potential of many thiophene monomers is higher than the oxidation potential of the resulting polymer. In other words, the polymer can be irreversibly oxidized and decompose at a rate comparable to the polymerization of the corresponding monomer.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} This remains one of the major disadvantages of electrochemical polymerization, and limits its application for many thiophene monomers with complex side groups.
===Chemical synthesis=== Chemical synthesis offers two advantages compared with electrochemical synthesis of PTs: a greater selection of monomers, and, using the proper catalysts, the ability to synthesize perfectly regioregular substituted PTs. While PTs may have been chemically synthesized by accident more than a century ago,<ref>{{cite journal |last=Meyer |first=Victor |authorlink=Viktor Meyer |title=Ueber den Begleiter des Benzols im Steinkohlentheer |language=German |trans-title=On the companion of benzene in stone coal <!-- better translation required --> |journal=[[Berichte der deutschen chemischen Gesellschaft]] |date=January–June 1883 |volume=16 |issue=1 |pages=1465–1478 |doi=10.1002/cber.188301601324}}</ref> the first planned chemical syntheses using metal-catalyzed polymerization of 2,5-dibromothiophene were reported by two groups independently in 1980. Yamamoto ''et al.'' used [[magnesium]] in [[tetrahydrofuran]] (THF) and nickel(bipyridine) dichloride, analogous to the [[Kumada coupling]] of Grignard reagents to aryl halides.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Yamamoto |first1=Takakazu |first2=Kenichi |last2=Sanechika |first3=Akio |last3=Yamamoto |title=Preparation of thermostable and electric-conducting poly(2,5-thienylene) |journal=Journal of Polymer Science C |date=January 1980 |volume=18 |issue=1 |pages=9–12 |doi=10.1002/pol.1980.130180103}}</ref> Lin and Dudek also used magnesium in THF, but with a series of [[acetylacetone|acetylacetonate]] catalysts ([[palladium(II) acetylacetonate|Pd(acac)<sub>2</sub>]], [[nickel(II) acetylacetonate|Ni(acac)<sub>2</sub>]], [[Metal acetylacetonates#Cobalt acetylacetonates|Co(acac)<sub>2</sub>]], and [[Tris(acetylacetonato)iron(III)|Fe(acac)<sub>3</sub>]].<ref>{{cite journal |first1=John W-P. |last1=Lin |first2=Lesley P. |last2=Dudek |title =Synthesis and properties of poly(2,5-thienylene) |journal=Journal of Polymer Science A|date=September 1980 |volume=18 |issue=9 |pages=2869–2873 |doi=10.1002/pol.1980.170180910}}</ref>
Later developments produced higher molecular weight PTs than those initial efforts, and can be grouped into two categories based on their structure. Regioregular PTs can be synthesized by catalytic cross-coupling reactions of bromothiophenes, while polymers with varying degrees of regioregularity can be simply synthesized by oxidative polymerization.
Regioregular PTs were described by McCullough ''et al.'' in 1992.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1039/C39920000070|title=Enhanced electrical conductivity in regioselectively synthesized poly(3-alkylthiophenes)|year=1992|last1=McCullough|first1=Richard D.|last2=Lowe|first2=Renae D.|journal=Journal of the Chemical Society, Chemical Communications|pages=70|issue=1}}</ref> As shown in Figure 5 (top), [[Image:Polythiophenes Crosscoupling.png|frame|'''Figure 5.''' Cross-coupling methods for preparing regioregular PATs.]] selective bromination produces 2-bromo-3-alkylthiophene, which is followed by lithiation, [[transmetalation]] and then [[Kumada coupling|Kumada cross-coupling]] in the presence of a nickel catalyst. This method produces approximately 100% HT–HT couplings, according to NMR spectroscopy analysis of the diads. In the method subsequently described by Rieke ''et al.'' in 1993,<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ma00065a036|title=Use of highly reactive zinc leads to a new, facile synthesis for polyarylenes|year=1993|last1=Chen|first1=Tian An|last2=O'Brien|first2=Richard A.|last3=Rieke|first3=Reuben D.|journal=Macromolecules|volume=26|pages=3462|issue=13}}</ref> 2,5-dibromo-3-alkylthiophene is treated with highly reactive "Rieke zinc"<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/jo00004a021|title=The direct formation of functionalized alkyl(aryl)zinc halides by oxidative addition of highly reactive zinc with organic halides and their reactions with acid chlorides, .alpha.,.beta.-unsaturated ketones, and allylic, aryl, and vinyl halides|year=1991|last1=Zhu|first1=Lishan|last2=Wehmeyer|first2=Richard M.|last3=Rieke|first3=Reuben D.|journal=The Journal of Organic Chemistry|volume=56|pages=1445|issue=4}}</ref> to form a mixture of organometallic isomers (Figure 5, bottom). Addition of a catalytic amount of Pd(PPh<sub>3</sub>)<sub>4</sub> produces a regiorandom polymer, but treatment with Ni(dppe)Cl<sub>2</sub> yields regioregular PAT in quantitative yield.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ja00051a066|title=The first regioregular head-to-tail poly(3-hexylthiophene-2,5-diyl) and a regiorandom isopolymer: nickel versus palladium catalysis of 2(5)-bromo-5(2)-(bromozincio)-3-hexylthiophene polymerization|year=1992|last1=Chen|first1=Tian An|last2=Rieke|first2=Reuben D.|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|volume=114|pages=10087|issue=25}}</ref>
While the McCullough and Rieke methods produce structurally homogenous PATs, they require low temperatures, the careful exclusion of water and oxygen, and brominated monomers. In contrast, the oxidative polymerization of thiophenes using ferric chloride described by Sugimoto in 1986 can be performed at room temperature under less demanding conditions.<ref name="sugimoto_etal_1986">{{cite journal |last1=Sugimoto |first1=R. |last2=Taketa |first2=S. |last3=Gu |first3=H. B. |last4=Yoshino |first4=K |title=Preparation of soluble polythiophene derivatives utilizing transition metal halides as catalysts and their property |journal=Chemistry Express |volume=1 |issue=11 |pages=635–638 |year=1986}}</ref> This method has proven to be extremely popular; antistatic coatings are prepared on a commercial scale using ferric chloride (see [[Polythiophene#Applications|below]]).<ref>Jonas, F.; Heywang, G.; Schmidtberg, W.; Heinze, J.; Dietrich, M. {{US patent|5035926}}, 1991.</ref>
A number of studies have been conducted in attempts to improve the yield and quality of the product obtained using the oxidative polymerization technique. In addition to ferric chloride, other oxidizing agents, including ferric chloride hydrate, copper [[perchlorate]], and iron perchlorate have also been used successfully to polymerize 2,2'-bithiophene.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/0379-6779(91)91817-T|title=Polythiophene and polythiophene-based conducting composites|year=1991|last1=Ruckenstein|first1=E.|last2=Park|first2=J.|journal=Synthetic Metals|volume=44|pages=293|issue=3}}</ref> Slow addition of ferric chloride to the monomer solution produced poly(3-(4-octylphenyl)thiophene)s with approximately 94% H–T content.<ref name="andersson_etal_1994" /> Precipitation of ferric chloride in situ (in order to maximize the surface area of the catalyst) produced significantly higher yields and monomer conversions than adding monomer directly to crystalline catalyst.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/0379-6779(95)03401-5|title=Ester-functionalized poly(3-alkylthienylene)s: substituent effects on the polymerization with FeCl<sub>3</sub>|year=1995|last1=Costa Bizzarri|first1=P.|journal=Synthetic Metals|volume=75|pages=141|issue=2|last2=Andreani|first2=Franco|last3=Della Casa|first3=Carlo|last4=Lanzi|first4=Massimiliano|last5=Salatelli|first5=Elisabetta}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ma0348730|title=Investigation on Different Procedures in the Oxidative Copolymerization of a Dye-Functionalized Thiophene with 3-Hexylthiophene|year=2003|last1=Fraleoni-Morgera|first1=Alessandro|last2=Della-Casa|first2=Carlo|last3=Lanzi|first3=Massimiliano|last4=Costa-Bizzarri|first4=Paolo|journal=Macromolecules|volume=36|pages=8617|issue=23}}</ref> Higher molecular weights were reported when dry air was bubbled through the reaction mixture during polymerization.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/0379-6779(91)91505-5|title=Processable polymers and copolymers of 3-alkylthiophenes and their blends|year=1991|last1=Pomerantz|first1=M.|last2=Tseng|first2=J.|last3=Zhu|first3=H.|last4=Sproull|first4=S.|last5=Reynolds|first5=J.|last6=Uitz|first6=R.|last7=Arnott|first7=H.|last8=Haider|first8=M.|journal=Synthetic Metals|volume=41|pages=825|issue=3}}</ref> Exhaustive [[Soxhlet extractor|Soxhlet extraction]] after polymerization with polar solvents was found to effectively fractionate the polymer and remove residual catalyst before NMR spectroscopy.<ref name="barbarella_etal_1994" /> Using a lower ratio of catalyst to monomer (2:1, rather than 4:1) may increase the regioregularity of poly(3-dodecylthiophene)s.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0379-6779(00)00233-2|title=Poly(3-dodecylthiophenes) polymerized with different amounts of catalyst|year=2000|last1=Qiao|first1=X.|journal=Synthetic Metals|volume=114|pages=261|issue=3|last2=Wang|first2=Xianhong|last3=Zhao|first3=Xiaojiang|last4=Liu|first4=Jian|last5=Mo|first5=Zhishen}}</ref> Andreani ''et al.'' reported higher yields of soluble poly(dialkylterthiophene)s in [[carbon tetrachloride]] rather than chloroform, which they attributed to the stability of the radical species in carbon tetrachloride.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Andreani |first1=F. |last2=Salatelli |first2=E. |last3=Lanzi |first3=M. |title=Novel poly(3,3'' – and 3',4'-dialkyl- 2,2':5',2'' – terthiophene)s by chemical oxidative synthesis: evidence for a new step towards the optimization of this process |journal=Polymer |date=February 1996 |volume=37 |issue=4 |pages=661–665 |doi=10.1016/0032-3861(96)83153-3}}</ref> Higher-quality catalyst, added at a slower rate and at reduced temperature, was shown to produce high molecular weight PATs with no insoluble polymer residue.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/S0379-6779(01)00665-8|title=Critical parameters for product quality and yield in the polymerisation of 3,3"-didodecyl-2,2′:5′,2"-terthiophene|year=2002|last1=Gallazzi|first1=M.|journal=Synthetic Metals|volume=128|pages=91|last2=Bertarelli|first2=C.|last3=Montoneri|first3=E.}}</ref> Laakso ''et al.'' used a [[Factorial experiment|factorial design]] to determine that increasing the ratio of catalyst to monomer increased the yield of poly(3-octylthiophene), and claimed that a longer polymerization time also increased the yield.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/0379-6779(93)90225-L|title=Recent developments in the polymerization of 3-alkylthiophenes|year=1993|last1=Laakso|first1=J.|last2=Jarvinen|first2=H.|last3=Skagerberg|first3=B.|journal=Synthetic Metals|volume=55|pages=1204|issue=2–3}}</ref>
The mechanism of the oxidative polymerization using ferric chloride has been controversial. Sugimoto ''et al.'' did not speculate on a mechanism in their 1986 report.<ref name="sugimoto_etal_1986" /> In 1992, Niemi ''et al.'' proposed a radical mechanism, shown in Figure 6(top). [[Image:Polythiophenes FeCl3 mechanisms.png|frame|'''Figure 6.''' Proposed mechanisms for ferric chloride oxidative polymerizations of thiophenes.]] They based their mechanism on two assumptions. First, since they observed polymerization only in solvents where the catalyst was either partially or completely insoluble (chloroform, [[toluene]], carbon tetrachloride, [[pentane]], and [[hexane]], and not [[diethyl ether]], [[xylene]], acetone, or [[formic acid]]), they concluded that the active sites of the polymerization must be at the surface of solid ferric chloride. Therefore, they discounted the possibilities of either two radical cations reacting with each other, or two radicals reacting with each other, "because the chloride ions at the surface of the crystal would prevent the radical cations or radicals from assuming positions suitable for dimerization".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Niemi |first1=V. M. |last2=Knuuttila |first2=P. |last3=Österholm |first3=J. E. |last4=Korvola |first4=J. |title=Polymerization of 3-alkylthiophenes with ferric chloride |journal=Polymer |volume=33 |pages=1559–1562 |doi=10.1016/0032-3861(92)90138-M |year=1992 |issue=7}}.</ref> Second, using 3-methylthiophene as a prototypical monomer, they performed [[Computational chemistry|quantum mechanical calculations]] to determine the energies and the total atomic charges on the carbon atoms of the four possible polymerization species (neutral 3-methylthiophene, the radical cation, the radical on carbon 2, and the radical on carbon 5).
[[Image:Polythiophenes 3mt.PNG|100px|3-methylthiophene]]
Since the most negative carbon of the neutral 3-methylthiophene is also carbon 2, and the carbon with the highest odd electron population of the radical cation is carbon 2, they concluded that a radical cation mechanism would lead to mostly 2–2, H–H links. They then calculated the total energies of the species with the radicals at the 2 and the 5 carbons, and found that the latter was more stable by 1.5 kJ/mol. Therefore, the more stable radical could react with the neutral species, forming head-to-tail couplings as shown in Figure 6 (top).
Andersson ''et al.'' offered an alternative mechanism in the course of their studies of the polymerization of 3-(4-octylphenyl)thiophene with ferric chloride, where they found a high degree of regioregularity when the catalyst was added to the monomer mixture slowly. They concluded that, given the selectivity of the couplings, and the strong oxidizing conditions, the reaction could proceed via a carbocation mechanism (Figure 6, middle).<ref name="andersson_etal_1994" />
The radical mechanism was directly challenged in a short communication in 1995, when Olinga and François noted that thiophene could be polymerized by ferric chloride in acetonitrile, a solvent in which the catalyst is completely soluble. Their analysis of the kinetics of thiophene polymerization also seemed to contradict the predictions of the [[radical polymerization]] mechanism.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/0379-6779(94)02457-A|title=Kinetics of polymerization of thiophene by FeCl<sub>3</sub> in choloroform and acetonitrile|year=1995|last1=Olinga|first1=T.|journal=Synthetic Metals|volume=69|pages=297|last2=François|first2=B.}}</ref> Barbarella ''et al.'' studied the oligomerization of 3-(alkylsulfanyl)thiophenes, and concluded from their quantum mechanical calculations, and considerations of the enhanced stability of the radical cation when delocalized over a planar conjugated oligomer, that a radical cation mechanism analogous to that generally accepted for electrochemical polymerization was more likely (Figure 6, bottom).<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/jo960982j|title=Regioselective Oligomerization of 3-(Alkylsulfanyl)thiophenes with Ferric Chloride|pmid=11667817|year=1996|last1=Barbarella|first1=Giovanna|last2=Zambianchi|first2=Massimo|last3=Di Toro|first3=Rosanna|last4=Colonna|first4=Martino|last5=Iarossi|first5=Dario|last6=Goldoni|first6=Francesca|last7=Bongini|first7=Alessandro|journal=The Journal of Organic Chemistry|volume=61|issue=23|pages=8285–8292}}</ref> Given the difficulties of studying a system with a heterogeneous, strongly oxidizing catalyst that produces difficult to characterize rigid-rod polymers, the mechanism of oxidative polymerization is by no means decided. However, the radical cation mechanism shown in Figure 6 is generally accepted as the most likely route for PT synthesis.
==Applications== [[File:Polythiophenes Pedotpss.png|thumb|left|'''Figure 7.''' PEDOT-PSS ([[Clevios]] P).]]As an example of a static application, [[PEDOT|poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)-poly(styrene sulfonate) (PEDOT-PSS)]] product ("Clevios P", see figure) from [[Heraeus]] has been extensively used as an antistatic coating (as packaging materials for electronic components, for example). [[Agfa-Gevaert|AGFA]] coats 200 m × 10 m of [[photographic film]] per year with PEDOT:PSS because of its [[antistatic]] properties. The thin layer of PEDOT:PSS is virtually transparent and colorless, prevents electrostatic discharges during film rewinding, and reduces dust buildup on the negatives after processing.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
PEDOT also have been proposed for dynamic applications where a potential is applied to a polymer film. PEDOT-coated windows and mirrors become opaque or reflective upon the application of an electric potential, a manifestation of its [[electrochromism|electrochromic properties]].<ref name="heuer_etal_2002" /> Widespread adoption of [[electrochromic]] windows promise significant savings in [[air conditioning]] costs.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rosseinsky|first1=D. R.|last2=Mortimer|first2=R. J.|title=Electrochromic Systems and the Prospects for Devices|journal=Advanced Materials|volume=13|pages=783|year=2001|doi=10.1002/1521-4095(200106)13:11<783::AID-ADMA783>3.0.CO;2-D|issue=11}}</ref> [[Image:Polythiophenes Crownethers.png|frame|'''Figure 8.''' Ionoselective PTs reported by Bäuerle (left) and Swager (right).]]
==Proposed applications== A number of applications have been proposed for conducting PTs, but have not achieved commercialization. Potential applications include [[field-effect transistors]],<ref>Garnier, F. "Field-Effect Transistors Based on Conjugated Materials". In ''Electronic Materials: The Oligomer Approach'' (Eds: Müllen, K.; Wegner, G.), Wiley-VCH, Weinheim, 1998, {{ISBN|3-527-29438-4}}</ref> [[Electroluminescence|electroluminescent devices]], [[solar cell]]s, [[Photoresist|photochemical resists]], [[Nonlinear optics|nonlinear optic devices]],<ref>Harrison, M. G.; Friend, R. H. "Optical Applications". In ''Electronic Materials: The Oligomer Approach'' (Eds: Müllen, K.; Wegner, G.), Wiley-VCH, Weinheim, 1998, {{ISBN|3-527-29438-4}}</ref> [[Battery (electricity)|batteries]], [[diode]]s, and chemical [[sensor]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Martina |first1=V |last2=Ionescu |first2=K. |last3=Pigani |first3=L |last4=Terzi |first4=F |last5=Ulrici |first5=A. |last6=Zanardi |first6=C. |last7=Seeber |first7=R |title=Development of an electronic tongue based on a PEDOT-modified voltammetric sensor |journal=Analytical and Bioanalytical Chemistry |date=March 2007 |volume=387 |issue=6 |pages=2101–2110 |doi=10.1007/s00216-006-1102-1 |pmid=17235499}}</ref> In general, there are two categories of applications for conducting polymers. Static applications rely upon the intrinsic [[electrical conductivity|conductivity]] of the materials, combined with their ease of processing and material properties common to polymeric materials. Dynamic applications utilize changes in the conductive and optical properties, resulting either from application of electric potentials or from environmental stimuli.
PTs have been touted as sensor elements. In addition to [[sensor|biosensor applications]], PTs can also be functionalized with receptors for detecting metal ions or [[optical isomer|chiral molecules]] as well. PTs with pendant [[crown ether]] functionalities exhibit properties that vary with the alkali metal.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/adma.19930051113|title=Molecular recognition of alkali-ions by crown-ether-functionalized poly(alkylthiophenes)|year=1993|last1=Bäuerle|first1=Peter|last2=Scheib|first2=Stefan|journal=Advanced Materials|volume=5|pages=848|issue=11}}</ref> and main-chain<ref name="marsella_and_swager_1993" />(Figure 8).
[[Image:Polythiophenes Goto.png|frame|'''Figure 9.''' Chiral PT synthesized by Yashima and Goto.]]
Chiral PTs in principle could be employed for detection of chiral analytes.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Goto|first1=Hidetoshi|last2=Okamoto|first2=Yoshio|last3=Yashima|first3=Eiji|title=Metal-Induced Supramolecular Chirality in an Optically Active Polythiophene Aggregate|journal=Chemistry: A European Journal|volume=8|pages=4027–36|year=2002|doi=10.1002/1521-3765(20020902)8:17<4027::AID-CHEM4027>3.0.CO;2-Q|pmid=12360944|issue=17}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ma012083p|title=Solvent-Induced Chiroptical Changes in Supramolecular Assemblies of an Optically Active, Regioregular Polythiophene|year=2002|last1=Goto|first1=Hidetoshi|last2=Okamoto|first2=Yoshio|last3=Yashima|first3=Eiji|journal=Macromolecules|volume=35|pages=4590|issue=12}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ja025900p|pmid=12095338|title=Electron-Induced Switching of the Supramolecular Chirality of Optically Active Polythiophene Aggregates|year=2002|last1=Goto|first1=Hidetoshi|last2=Yashima|first2=Eiji|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|volume=124|issue=27|pages=7943–9}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ol016189g|pmid=11463321|title=Synthesis and Chiroptical Properties of Optically Active, Regioregular Oligothiophenes|year=2001|last1=Sakurai|first1=Shin-Ichiro|last2=Goto|first2=Hidetoshi|last3=Yashima|first3=Eiji|journal=Organic Letters|volume=3|issue=15|pages=2379–82}}</ref> Yashima and Goto found a PT with a chiral primary [[amine]] (Figure 9) <ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ma9912305|title=Metal-Induced Chirality Induction and Chiral Recognition of Optically Active, Regioregular Polythiophenes|year=1999|last1=Yashima|first1=Eiji|last2=Goto|first2=Hidetoshi|last3=Okamoto|first3=Yoshio|journal=Macromolecules|volume=32|pages=7942|issue=23}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1039/C39880000658|title=Enantioselective chiral poly(thiophenes)|year=1988|last1=Lemaire|first1=Marc|last2=Delabouglise|first2=Didier|last3=Garreau|first3=Robert|last4=Guy|first4=Alain|last5=Roncali|first5=Jean|journal=Journal of the Chemical Society, Chemical Communications|pages=658|issue=10}}</ref>
Fluorinated polythiophene yield 7% efficiency in polymer-fullerene solar cells.<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Samuel C. |last1=Price |first2=Andrew C. |last2=Stuart |first3=Liqiang |last3=Yang |first4=Huaxing |last4=Zhou |first5=Wei |last5=You |title=Fluorine Substituted Conjugated Polymer of Medium Band Gap Yields 7% Efficiency in Polymer−Fullerene Solar Cells |journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society |year=2011 |volume=133 |issue=12 |pages=4625–4631| doi=10.1021/ja1112595 |pmid=21375339}}</ref>
{{As of|2012}}, research has identified polythiophenes as a potential agent in the treatment of [[Transmissible spongiform encephalopathy|prion diseases]].<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Ilan |last1=Margalith |first2=Carlo |last2=Suter |first3=Boris |last3=Ballmer |first4=Petra |last4=Schwarz |title=Polythiophenes Inhibit Prion Propagation by Stabilizing Prion Protein (PrP) Aggregates |year=2012 |journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry |pmid=22493452 |doi=10.1074/jbc.M112.35595 |volume=287 |pmc=3365923 |pages=18872–87}}</ref>

'''Project Bacchus''' was a covert investigation by the [[Defense Threat Reduction Agency]] [[US Defense Department]] to determine whether it is possible to construct a [[bioweapon]]s production facility with off-the-shelf equipment.
==History==
===The project=== Project Bacchus operated from 1999-2000 to investigate whether would-be terrorists could build an [[anthrax]] production facility and remain undetected.<ref name=enemark/> During the two-year simulation, the facility was constructed, and successfully produced an anthrax-like [[bacterium]].<ref name=mac/> The participating scientists were able to make about {{convert|1|kg}} of highly refined bacterial particles.<ref name=mac>MacKenzie, Debora. [https://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn1449 Anthrax in Florida and New York "the same strain"]", ''[[New Scientist]]'', October 18, 2001. Retrieved January 6, 2009.</ref>
===Reportage=== The secret Project Bacchus was disclosed in a September 2001 article in ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref name=enemark/> Reporters [[Judith Miller (journalist)|Judith Miller]], Stephen Engelberg and [[William J. Broad]] collaborated on the article.<ref name=enemark/> Shortly after it appeared, they published a book containing further details.<ref name=enemark/> The book, ''[[Germs: Biological Weapons and America's Secret War]]'', and the article are the only publicly available sources{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} concerning Project Bacchus and its sister projects, [[Project Clear Vision|Clear Vision]] and [[Project Jefferson|Jefferson]].<ref name=enemark>Enemark, Christian. ''Disease and Security: Natural Plagues and Biological Weapons in East Asia'', ([https://books.google.com/books?id=bT9j6lhPHHUC&pg=PA173&dq=%22Project+Clear+Vision%22&client=firefox-a#PPA174,M1 Google Books]), Routledge, 2007, pp. 173-75, ({{ISBN|0415422345}}).</ref>

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} [[File:Rudyard Kipling by Sir Philip Burne-Jones 1899.jpeg|thumb|right|[[Rudyard Kipling]], author of the ritual]] [[Image:Haultain.gif|thumb|right|[[H. E. T. Haultain]] conceived the ritual and requested Kipling to create it.]] The '''Ritual of the Calling of an Engineer''' is a private [[ritual]], authored by [[Rudyard Kipling]], in which students about to graduate from an engineering program at a university in Canada are permitted to participate. Participation may also be permitted for Canadian [[professional engineer]]s and registered engineers-in-training who received training elsewhere. The ritual is administered by a body called [[Ritual of the Calling of an Engineer#Corporation of the Seven Wardens|The Corporation of the Seven Wardens]].<ref name="ritual">"[http://www.ironring.ca The Ritual of the Calling of an Engineer ]", ''[[#The Corporation of the Seven Wardens|The Corporation of the Seven Wardens]]'', Retrieved 4 April 2010</ref> As part of the ritual each participant is conferred the [[Iron Ring]].
==History== The ritual traces its origins to professor [[H. E. T. Haultain]] of the [[University of Toronto]], who believed and persuaded other members of the [[Engineering Institute of Canada]] that there needed to be a ceremony and standard of ethics developed for graduating engineers. The ritual was created in 1922 by [[Rudyard Kipling]] at the request of Haultain, representing seven past-presidents of the [[Engineering Institute of Canada]].<ref name="hist_finger"/><ref name="iron_ring">"[http://www.eir.ca/engineers/ironring.php?link=4 Engineer-in-Residence/ Iron Ring] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706175651/http://www.eir.ca/engineers/ironring.php?link=4 |date=6 July 2011 }}", ''[[Professional Engineers Ontario]]'', Retrieved 4 April 2010</ref> The seven past-presidents were the original seven Wardens of the Corporation.
{{quote|The Ritual of the Calling of an Engineer has been instituted with the simple end of directing the young engineer towards a consciousness of his profession and its significance, and indicating to the older engineer his responsibilities in receiving, welcoming and supporting the young engineers in their beginnings.|Rudyard Kipling|from notes by Dr. J. Jeswiet<ref>[http://www.networx.on.ca/~njdevil/mainpage/E_Eng/Academic/jj-ring.htm Dr. J. Jeswiet: Information Relevant to the Iron Ring Ceremony] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706192330/http://www.networx.on.ca/~njdevil/mainpage/E_Eng/Academic/jj-ring.htm |date=6 July 2011 }}</ref>}}
An inaugural ceremony was held in the evening of 25 April 1925, at the University Club of Montreal, when the obligation was taken by six engineers,<ref>R.A. Ross, Consulting Engineer, acting as the Senior Supervising Engineer of the ceremony; J.M.R. Fairbairn, Chief Engineer, Canadian Pacific Railway; Harold Rolph, President, John S. Metcalf and Co., Consulting Engineers; N.M. Lash, Chief Engineer, Bell Telephone Co.; J.M. Robertson, Consulting Engineer; and John Chalmers, Engineer for John Quinlan & Co., Contractors.</ref> some of whom were involved with Kipling in its development. On 1 May 1925, three of these newly obligated engineers<ref>Dr. Ross, Dr. Fairbairn and Mr. Rolph.</ref> met at the University of Toronto with a number of the officers of the Engineering Alumni Association and obligated 14 of them in the Senate Chamber of the university becoming the first local chapter (referred to as a camp) to do so. Fairbairn met with Harry F. McLean, president of Dominion Construction and Kipling in Montreal at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel to discuss the details of the ritual. Fairbairn later visited McLean at his home in Merrickville, Ontario, to secure a sizeable donation from McLean, philanthropist, on behalf of the Corporation of the Seven Wardens, the custodian and administrator of the ritual, to ensure its survival. The Ritual and the conferring of the Iron Ring continues to be administered by The Corporation of the Seven Wardens Inc./''Société des Sept Gardiens inc.'' through camps<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ironring.ca/contact.php|title=Camp Contacts - The Iron Ring|website=www.IronRing.ca|access-date=15 November 2017}}</ref> associated with the universities granting degrees in engineering in Canada.
==Ritual== The ritual takes place separately at individual Camps across Canada usually situated near an engineering university. The ceremonies are separate, organised by one of 26 camps of the Corporation of the Seven Wardens for administrative purposes.
[[File:Ritual of the Calling of an Engineer Oath.jpg|thumb|right|The obligation spoken by Canadian Engineers at the Ritual of the Calling of an Engineer]] The [[moral obligation|Obligation]], which is not an [[oath]] but a solemn expression of intention, is subscribed to at the [[ceremony]]. The Obligation essentially states the duties and responsibilities of the engineer. Following the Obligation, the [[Iron Ring]] is placed on the [[little finger]] of the working hand,<ref name="hist_finger">"[http://www.order-of-the-engineer.org/?page_id=15 Order Of The Engineer-History ]", ''[[Order of the Engineer]].org'', Retrieved 4 April 2010</ref> and is worn by the engineer as a [[symbol]] and a reminder. As originally conceived, the engineer's iron ring rubs against the drawings and paper upon which the Engineer writes and even in modern times, serves as a reminder when working on a computer.
The Obligation is [[privacy|private]], though not necessarily [[secrecy|secret]].<ref name="ringceremony"/> However, it is customary for those who have gone through it to not discuss the details of the Calling with others, even engineers from other countries. The ceremony is open only to candidates or those who have already undergone the ritual.<ref name="ringceremony">Compiled by Dr. J. Jeswiet, "[http://www.networx.on.ca/~njdevil/mainpage/E_Eng/Academic/jj-ring.htm#4 Information Relevant to the Iron Ring Ceremony ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706192330/http://www.networx.on.ca/~njdevil/mainpage/E_Eng/Academic/jj-ring.htm |date=6 July 2011 }}", 22 November 2001; Retrieved 4 April 2010</ref>
As part of the preparation for the ritual, candidates are instructed not to discuss the details of the ritual with the media. A reminder of this is provided at the end of the ceremony in the form of a written instruction that states: "''The Rule of Governance provides that there shall be no publicity in connection with the Ritual." ''<ref name="ringceremony"/>
Commemorating the 75th anniversary, the Ritual of the Calling of an Engineer domestic-rate stamp was issued on 25 April 2000. Designer Darrell Freeman's "head-to-foot" layout incorporates the symbolic iron ring that is presented as part of the ceremony. The ring also visually links the four engineering achievements featured on this stamp.<ref name="comm_stamp">"[http://www.canadapost.ca/cpo/mc/personal/collecting/stamps/archives/2000/2000_apr_ritual.jsf Commemorative Stamp-Ritual of the Calling of an Engineer, 1925–2000 ]", ''[[Canada Post]]'', 25 April 2000; Retrieved 4 April 2010</ref>
The Ritual of the Calling of an Engineer has a very simple purpose: To direct the newly qualified engineer toward a consciousness of the profession and its social significance and indicating to the more experienced engineer their responsibilities in welcoming and supporting the newer engineers when they are ready to enter the profession.<ref name="camp1">{{cite web|url=https://www.camp1.ca/wordpress/?page_id=2|title=The Wardens of Camp One - The Calling of an Engineer|website=www.Camp1.ca|access-date=15 November 2017}}</ref>
The ring symbolizes the pride which engineers have in their profession, while simultaneously reminding them of their humility. The ring serves as a reminder to the engineer and others of the engineer’s obligation to live by a high standard of professional conduct.<ref name="camp1"/>
==Iron Ring== {{main|Iron Ring}} [[File:Ironring2005.JPG|thumb|200px|Iron Ring, iron version, circa 2005]] The Iron Ring may be made from either iron or [[stainless steel]]. Presently, only Camp One of the Corporation in [[Toronto]] continues to confer rings made from iron; stainless steel rings are conferred at all other locations across Canada. The Iron Ring does not certify a person as a [[Professional Engineer]],<ref name="ritual"/> which requires registration with a relevant professional organisation followed by examination and practical experience.
==Corporation of the Seven Wardens== The Corporation of the Seven Wardens (French: ''Société des Sept Gardiens'') is the body that holds the rights and the duty to carry out The Ritual of the Calling of an Engineer. It is organised into 26 regional branches, called ''camps'', numbered by order of establishment. The term ''camp'' is used to describe these regional branches because it conveys a smaller, close-knit sense of community.

revision.comment: Added Symposia 2019 and a short summary for Symposia 2018.
revision.text:
The '''Symposia on VLSI Technology and Circuits''' are two closely connected international conferences on [[semiconductor]] technology and circuits, thereby offering an opportunity to interact and synergize on topics of joint interest, spanning the range from process technology to systems-on-chip.<ref>[http://www.electroiq.com/articles/sst/2013/04/breakthroughs-in-transistors--interconnects-and-integrated-circu.html Breakthroughs in transistors and more to be discussed at VLSI Symposia 2013] (ElectroIQ 2013)</ref> <ref>[http://www.realworldtech.com/intel-dram Intel’s Long Awaited Return to the Memory Business] (Real World Technologies 2013)</ref> <ref>[http://sscs.ieee.org/images/files/news/2013-05-28%20vlsi-symposia%202013%20sscs%20head-line%20news%20proposal-ed.doc Premier mid-year gatherings for microelectronics engineers, managers and researchers] (IEEE SSCS 2013)</ref> <ref>[http://spectrum.ieee.org/robotics/military-robots/roachnet-radio Roach-Net Radio - The son of the cyborg moth is a radio-equipped cockroach] (IEEE Spectrum 2013)</ref> <ref>[http://www.eetimes.com/electronics-news/4044532/VLSI-symposium-eyes-65-nm-logic VLSI Symposium eyes 65-nm logic] (EETIMES 2003)</ref> <ref>[http://www.eetimes.com/electronics-news/4048639/VLSI-papers-weigh-65-nm-new-circuits-item-1 VLSI papers weigh 65 nm, new circuits] (EETIMES 2004)</ref> <ref>[http://www.electroiq.com/articles/sst/2007/08/centeraugust-2007-exclusive-feature-2brvlsi-symposium-report-chipmakers-consortia-reveal-hkmg-integration-center.html VLSI SYMPOSIUM REPORT: Chipmakers, consortia reveal HK+MG integration] (ElectroIQ 2007)</ref> <ref>[http://www.electroiq.com/articles/sst/print/volume-51/issue-8/departments/tech-news/report-from-vlsi-symposium-planar-cmos-to-22nm-at-most.html Report from VLSI Symposium: Planar CMOS to 22nm, at most] (ElectroIQ 2008)</ref> <ref>[http://www.electroiq.com/articles/sst/2009/07/report-from-the-vlsi-symposium-less-spirited-still-informative.html Report from the VLSI Symposium: Less spirited, still informative] (ElectroIQ 2009)</ref> <ref>[http://www.eetimes.com/electronics-news/4375244/TI-details-TSV-integration-in-28-nm-CMOS TI details TSV integration in 28-nm CMOS] (EETIMES 2012)</ref> The Symposia take place once a year around the middle of June at locations alternating between [[Kyoto]], Japan and [[Honolulu]], USA. They bring together managers, engineers, and scientists from industry and academia around the world to discuss challenges in manufacturing and design of [[Very-large-scale integration]] (VLSI) circuits.<ref>[http://www.electroiq.com/blogs/chipworks_real_chips_blog/2012/04/intel-to-present-on-22-nm-tri-gate-technology-at-vlsi-symposium.html Intel to Present on 22-nm Tri-gate Technology at VLSI Symposium] (ElectroIQ 2012)</ref> The Symposium on VLSI Technology started in 1981 while the Symposium on VLSI Circuits was established in 1987.<ref>[http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/Xplore/login.jsp?url=http%3A%2F%2Fieeexplore.ieee.org%2Fiel1%2F4%2F12357%2F00568785.pdf%3Farnumber%3D568785&authDecision=-203 The Beginnings of the Symposium on VLSI Circuits] (JSSC 1997)</ref> Beside regular presentations of technical papers, the Symposia comprise short courses, panel sessions, and invited talks conducted by experts in the field from both Industry and Academia.
==Sponsors== The Symposium on VLSI Technology is sponsored by the [[IEEE Electron Devices Society]] and the [[Japan Society of Applied Physics]] in cooperation with the [[IEEE Solid-State Circuits Society]]. The Symposium on VLSI Circuits is sponsored by the [[IEEE Solid-State Circuits Society]] and the [[Japan Society of Applied Physics]] in cooperation with the Institute of Electronics, Information and Communication Engineers and the [[IEEE Electron Devices Society]]. Extended versions of selected papers from the Symposium on VLSI Circuits are regularly published once a year in a special Issue of the IEEE Journal of Solid-State Circuits. <ref>[http://sscs.ieee.org/ieee-journal-of-solid-state-circuits-jssc.html Journal of Solid-State Circuits] (JSSC)</ref>
== Symposia 2019 == The 2019 Symposia on VLSI Technology and Circuits will be held at the RIHGA Royal Hotel, [[Kyoto]], [[Japan]] between Sunday, 9-Jun-2019 and Friday, 14-Jun-2019. The Symposia theme for 2019 will be "Pushing the Limits of Semiconductors for United and Connected World."
The Symposia Call for Papers have been posted for both [http://vlsisymposium.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/Tech-1st-CFP_180921_rev1-002.pdf Technology] and [http://vlsisymposium.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/Circ-1st-CFP_180921_rev1-002.pdf Circuits]. There will be a Sunday Workshop on June 9th and a Short Course on June 10th. The technical program will be on June 11-13 followed by a Friday Forum on June 14th.
== Symposia 2018 == The 2018 Symposia on VLSI Technology and Circuits were held at the [[Hilton Hawaiian Village]], [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]] on June 18-22, 2018<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://vlsisymposium.org/2018/}}</ref>. * The conference theme for 2018 was ""Technology, Circuits and Systems for Smart Living." * The Circuits plenary session highlighted talks from [[Nvidia]] on [https://research.nvidia.com/publication/2018-06_Hardware-Enabled-Artificial-Intelligence "Hardware‐Enabled Artificial Intelligence"] and [https://www.secom.co.jp/english/corporate/outline/greeting/ SECOM] the use of semiconductor technologies that enable security systems. * The Technology plenary session featured the role of memory technology enabling future computing systems in a talk from [[Micron Technology]], as well as a presentation on AI-based cancer genomic medicine from [[University of Tokyo]].
== Symposia 2017 == The 2017 Symposia on VLSI Technology and Circuits were held at the RIHGA Royal Hotel, [[Kyoto]], [[Japan]] between Monday, 5-Jun-2017 and Thursday, 8-Jun-2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://electroiq.com/blog/2017/05/vlsi-communities-come-together-to-identify-new-dimensions-for-continuing-exponential-growth-beyond-moores-law/|title=VLSI communities come together to identify new dimensions...|last=|first=|date=|website=SolidState Technology Magazine|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://spectrum.ieee.org/nanoclast/semiconductors/devices/nanosheets-ibms-path-to-5nanometer-transistors|title=Nanosheets: IBM’s Path to 5-Nanometer Transistors|website=IEEE Spectrum: Technology, Engineering, and Science News|language=en|access-date=2017-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1331851&&cn=bWVudGlvbg==|title=IBM Optics Go CMOS {{!}} EE Times|website=EETimes|access-date=2017-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1331888|title=Germanium Displacing GaAs for RF Transistors {{!}} EE Times|website=EETimes|access-date=2017-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1331958|title=Embedded MRAM Can Take the Heat {{!}} EE Times|website=EETimes|access-date=2017-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/tech-talk/semiconductors/design/a-circuit-that-sees-radiation-strikes-could-keep-errors-at-bay|title=A Circuit That Sees Radiation Strikes Could Keep Errors at Bay|website=IEEE Spectrum: Technology, Engineering, and Science News|language=en|access-date=2017-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/aarontilley/2017/06/05/ibm-5nm-chips/#604583283c56|title=IBM Shows The World How To Build A Super Dense 5-Nanometer Chip|last=Tilley|first=Aaron|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-10-16|language=en}}</ref>. * For the first time, the Technology and Circuits Symposia fully overlapped, maximizing the opportunity to learn from and interact with experts from both sides of the conference. * The [http://vlsisymposium.org/2017/program/ advance technical program] for both Symposia are available online. * [http://vlsisymposium.org/2017/vlsi-technolog/#1491840095018-0e948159-05a2 Short courses] covered 5 nm technology enablers, machine learning, and circuits for autonomous vehicles. * VLSI Circuits Symposium 2017 hosted a new Demo Session, which will be held during the Symposium Joint Circuits/Technology Reception. At the demo session, authors of selected papers employed posters to augment their demonstrations. * The Circuits plenary session included talks by [[Google]] on Waymo's self-driving car and from [[Panasonic]] on the topic of an interconnected IoT world. * The Technology plenary session was headlined by talks from [[SoftBank Group|SoftBank]] and [[NXP Semiconductors]]. * Several evening panels were held, with a chance to hear from a variety of industrial and academic thought leaders. * A new [https://sites.google.com/site/jsps165/2017nendo/06ISE International Forum on Singularity: Exponential X] was held on Friday, 9-Jun-2017, and was free for all paid registrants of the VLSI Symposia.
== Symposia 2016 == The 2016 Symposia on VLSI Technology and Circuits was held at the [[Hilton Hawaiian Village]], [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]] between Monday, 13-Jun-2016 and Friday, 17-Jun-2016. * [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=7743073 IEEE SSCS Magazine] provides a summary report<ref>[http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=7743073 2016 Symposium on VLSI Circuits Explores Inflections for a Smart Society] (IEEE SSCS Magazine 3/2016))</ref> * The conference theme for 2016 was "VLSI Inflection for a Smart Society," reflecting the transition from More Moore to More Than Moore technologies in support of the increasingly connected society enabled by the Internet of Things. * The Circuits plenary session highlighted talks from [[Google]] on machine learning and [[Sony]] covering advances in and impact of image sensors. * The Technology plenary session featured the impact of MEMS sensors in a talk from [[InvenSense]], as well as a presentation on intelligent mobility from [[Nissan]]. * The Executive Panel, moderated by Dan Hutcheson of VLSI Research Inc., included industry leaders discussing the "Semiconductor Business: Inflections Beyond Scaling." * [http://vlsisymposium.org/Past/16web/program/ Technical Program]
== Symposia 2015 == The 2015 Symposia on VLSI Technology and Circuits were held at the [http://www.rihga.com/kyoto/ RIHGA Royal Hotel], [[Kyoto]], [[Japan]] between Monday, 15-Jun-2015 and Friday, 19-Jun-2015. * [http://www.vlsisymposium.org/Past/15web/program.html Technical Program] * Plenary sessions addressed robotics, technology needs for future consumer devices, commercialization of the [[Internet of Things]] (IoT), and autonomous driving. * Joint technology and circuits sessions covered design in scaled technologies, design enablement, memory technologies, and 3D-integration (TSV). * For the first time, the circuits symposium encouraged submissions of papers beyond the chip context in areas related to IoT sensing, industrial electronics, big data processing/storage systems, and robotics and smart car.
== Symposia 2014 == The 2014 Symposia on VLSI Technology and Circuits were held at the [[Hilton Hawaiian Village]], [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]] between Monday, 09-Jun-2014 and Friday, 13-Jun-2014. * '''[http://www.vlsisymposium.org/program/ Advance Program]''' * Joint circuit and technology focus sessions were offered in the following special topics of mutual interest: 3D Circuits & Applications, 3D Systems & Packaging, Design/Technology Co-Optimization, Non-volatile & Emerging Memory, and SRAM & DRAM.<ref>[http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/search/searchresult.jsp?newsearch=true&queryText=New+Joint+Sessions+at+the+2012+IEEE+Symposia+on+VLSI+Circuits+and+Technology&x=12&y=14 New Joint Sessions at the 2012 IEEE Symposia on VLSI Circuits and Technology] (IEEE SSCS Magazine 3/2012)</ref><ref>[http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=6393006 Eight Joint Sessions Spark Interdisciplinary Discussions at the 2012 VLSI Symposia] (IEEE SSCS Magazine 4/2012)</ref> * This year, a Luncheon & Executive Panel did debate on "Emerging Semiconductor Industry Trends and Implications" [http://www.vlsisymposium.org/program/ (Link)] * A joint technology-circuits panel session addressed the question: "Who Gives Up on Scaling First: Device & Process Technology Engineers, Circuit Designers or Company Executives? [http://www.vlsisymposium.org/plenary-rump-sessions/ (Link)] * The 2014 Symposia on VLSI Technology and Circuits were preceded by three full-day short courses: "High Performance Mobile SoCs Enabled by 10nm SoC Technology" [http://www.vlsisymposium.org/vlsi-technolog/ (Link)], "Advanced Data Converter & Mixed-Signal Circuit Design", and "Advanced Energy-Efficient Digital Design" ([http://www.vlsisymposium.org/vlsi-circuits/ Link]). * Also, the Symposia were accompanied by two satellite workshops, the [http://snw2014.insight-outside.fr/minatec/ 2014 Silicon Nanoelectronics Workshop] (June 8–9) and the [http://www.cies.tohoku.ac.jp/ja/cies/uploads/2014_Spintronics.pdf 2014 Spintronics Workshop on LSI] (June 9) at the same location.
== Symposia 2013 == The 2013 Symposia on VLSI Technology and Circuits were held in [[Kyoto]], Japan between 2013-06-11 and 2013-06-14 with more than 1000 microelectronics engineers, managers and researchers attending.<ref>[http://www.electroiq.com/articles/sst/2013/04/breakthroughs-in-transistors--interconnects-and-integrated-circu.html Breakthroughs in transistors and more to be discussed at VLSI Symposia 2013] (ElectroIQ 2013)</ref><ref>[http://www.realworldtech.com/intel-dram Intel’s Long Awaited Return to the Memory Business] (Real World Technologies 2013)</ref><ref>[http://sscs.ieee.org/images/files/news/2013-05-28%20vlsi-symposia%202013%20sscs%20head-line%20news%20proposal-ed.doc Premier mid-year gatherings for microelectronics engineers, managers and researchers] (IEEE SSCS 2013)</ref><ref>[http://spectrum.ieee.org/robotics/military-robots/roachnet-radio Roach-Net Radio - The son of the cyborg moth is a radio-equipped cockroach] (IEEE Spectrum 2013)</ref><ref>[http://electroiq.com/chipworks_real_chips_blog/2014/02/07/intels-e-dram-shows-up-in-the-wild Intel’s e-DRAM Shows Up In The Wild] (Solid State Technology 2014)</ref> * [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=6670202 IEEE SSCS Magazine] provides a summary report<ref>[http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=6670202 The 2013 Symposia on VLSI Technology and Circuits - Commemorating the Past and Heading into the Post Planar CMOS Future] (IEEE SSCS Magazine 4/2013))</ref> * The Technical Programs are available on the Symposia's web site ([http://www.vlsisymposium.org/circuits/technical.html Circuits] / [http://www.vlsisymposium.org/technology/technical.html Technology]). * Highlights of the technical program are provided in Chinese, Englisch, Japanese and Korean ([http://vlsisymposium.org/events/index.html Editor Press Center]) * The Symposia were accompanied by two satellite workshops, the [http://diana.pe.titech.ac.jp/~snw2013 2013 Silicon Nanoelectronics Workshop] (June 9–10) and the [http://www.csis.tohoku.ac.jp/files/2013_Spintronics_Workshop_on_LSI.pdf 2013 Spintronics Workshop on LSI] (June 10) at the same location.
